name: South Sudan
currentCrisisSummary:
South Sudan is in the grip of a severe, multi-dimensional humanitarian emergency driven by elite competition over oil revenues, recurrent climate-driven flooding, and regional spillover from Sudan's war.

A political economy of corruption and elite capture turns the state into a battlefield over oil rents, while climate extremes â€” notably catastrophic floods â€” have destroyed harvests and settlements, multiplying displacement and food insecurity. The conflict dynamics accelerated after 2013 have produced high mortality and enduring protection crises; renewed political tensions in 2025 risk reversing fragile gains in peace and humanitarian access.

The immediate needs are enormous: humanitarian planning for 2025 identifies millions in need of assistance, while the country hosts and produces one of Africa's largest refugee and displacement crises. Durable solutions require ending the impunity of predatory elites, ensuring accountability for abuses, and redirecting oil revenues and international finance toward locally led recovery and climate resilience.

colonialRoot.legacy:
British colonial administration pursued a 'Southern Policy' that governed the south separately from the north, entrenching political and economic divisions. This divide-and-rule approach limited investment in southern institutions and left a legacy of structural marginalisation that contributed to subsequent insurgency and weak governance.

The administrative boundaries, uneven development and externally mediated leadership formations created conditions that later made the territory vulnerable to elite predation and resource-capture after independence.

historicalContext.title: Neoliberal State-Building and the CPA
historicalContext.description: The 2005 Comprehensive Peace Agreement (CPA), heavily mediated by Western powers, was a fundamentally neoliberal peace-building project. The international community prioritised the creation of a market-based, oil-exporting state, focusing on technocratic elements like central banking and managing foreign investment. This model neglected grassroots reconciliation and failed to build a diversified economy. It created a hollow state whose sole purpose was the distribution of oil rents, making control of the state the only prize worth fighting for. The 2013 civil war was a direct and predictable outcome of this flawed, externally-imposed model of state formation.

historicalContext.title: Corruption and the Global Financial System
historicalContext.description: South Sudan's politics are shaped by an elite scramble for oil revenue. The state has functioned as an apparatus for capturing rents rather than delivering public goods. International banks, opaque corporate structures and the global financial system have enabled the laundering and concealment of stolen wealth, permitting elites to profit while public infrastructure and services collapse. This is not a passive failure; it is an active feature of a global financial system that provides safe havens for illicit capital, directly fuelling the conflict. Internationally enabled financial opacity and weak enforcement of due diligence are therefore structural enablers of the country's crisis.

historicalContext.title: Oil Conflict and Climate Challenges
historicalContext.description: The oil sector has fuelled rent-seeking and patronage networks; foreign energy companies operating in partnership with local elites have often prioritised extraction over community reinvestment. Simultaneously, extreme floods â€” worsened by global heating â€” have destroyed crops, displaced communities and aggravated food insecurity. Climate shocks act as a conflict multiplier in a state already weakened by governance failures.

historicalContext.title: International Law And Accountability
historicalContext.description: Serious violations of international humanitarian and human-rights law have been documented during cycles of violence. Independent research has estimated large numbers of excess deaths associated with the 2013-2018 civil war. Calls for accountability include proposals for a Hybrid Court for South Sudan and targeted sanctions on those who facilitate violence and steal public assets. Effective accountability must combine criminal responsibility for grave abuses with structural measures to recover stolen assets and reform resource governance.

humanitarianImpact.title: Casualties
humanitarianImpact.description: Nearly 400,000 excess deaths attributable to the conflict since 2013.

humanitarianImpact.title: Affected
humanitarianImpact.description: Roughly 9.4 million people in need of assistance (approximately two-thirds of the population).

humanitarianImpact.title: Food Insecurity
humanitarianImpact.description: Large population faces severe food insecurity driven by flooding, displacement and market disruption.

humanitarianImpact.title: Displaced
humanitarianImpact.description: Approximately 2.1 million people internally displaced within South Sudan, with combined displacement burden over 4 million including refugees and returnees.

humanitarianImpact.title: Refugees
humanitarianImpact.description: More than 2.3 million South Sudanese are refugees or asylum-seekers, one of Africa's largest refugee situations.

humanitarianImpact.title: Children Out of School
humanitarianImpact.description: Millions of children out of school due to conflict and displacement.

humanitarianImpact.title: Living in Poverty
humanitarianImpact.description: A majority of households face extreme poverty and food shortages.

timeline.event: **Anglo-Egyptian Condominium**: Britain administered the south under a 'Southern Policy' that separated it administratively from northern Sudan, entrenching regional inequalities.
**First Sudanese Civil War**: Southern rebellions for autonomy and justice begin before Sudan's independence, sowing the seeds of later fragmentation.
**Second Sudanese Civil War**: A brutal renewed war causes mass displacement and millions of deaths, creating conditions for later secession.

**Comprehensive Peace Agreement (CPA)**: A Western-mediated peace deal establishes a government based on sharing oil revenues. This neoliberal model of state-building creates a state designed for elite rent-capture, laying the groundwork for future conflict.
**Independence**: South Sudan becomes the world's newest state after a referendum, inheriting weak institutions and an oil-dependent economy.
**Civil War Erupts**: Political rivalry between elites escalates into wide-scale violence, producing mass displacement and severe humanitarian collapse.
**Revitalised Peace Agreement**: A fragile power-sharing agreement is signed but many core reforms, notably security-sector reform and accountability measures, remain incomplete.

**Renewed Tensions & Flooding**: Political tensions, contested prosecutions and catastrophic floods in recent years have combined to deepen displacement, food insecurity and protection risks, threatening fragile peace gains.

donate.description: A South Sudanese-led NGO providing emergency relief and community development programmes in contested and hard-to-reach areas.
Provides protection, shelter and assistance to refugees, returnees and internally displaced people in and from South Sudan.
Works with children and families affected by conflict to provide education, child protection services, and support for long-term livelihoods.
Delivers emergency food and nutrition support across South Sudan and is central to preventing famine during flood and conflict-related shocks.

advocacy: Push for targeted sanctions and asset-recovery measures against corrupt elites and intermediaries who divert oil revenues and undermine peace.
Advocate for establishment and proper funding of the Hybrid Court for South Sudan to ensure credible accountability for war crimes and crimes against humanity.
Demand that oil contracts and resource revenues be renegotiated with transparent, community-centred benefit-sharing and robust oversight.
Call for scaled, flexible humanitarian and climate finance that is channelled through South Sudanese organisations and local institutions to build resilience.

reading.title: A Rope from the Sky: The Making and Unmaking of the World's Newest State
reading.description: Zach Vertin's detailed reporting on South Sudan's formation, political failures and the collapse into civil war.

reading.title: First Raise a Flag: How South Sudan Won the Longest War but Lost the Peace
reading.description: Peter Martell's analysis of South Sudan's independence and the subsequent challenges that led to violent competition over the state.

reading.title: South Sudan: The Untold Story from Independence to Civil War
reading.description: Hilde F. Johnson's insider account of international state-building attempts and their failures in South Sudan.
